title: Ticket #7530: Fix negotiator diagnostic in "condor_q -analyze"
description:
Starting in #3585, schedds provide resource request lists (RRL) to the negotiator -- not jobs.

When a job associated with an RRL is rejected by the negotiator, the schedd makes a note of this in the job's ClassAd. condor_q -better-analyze understands this attribute and will inform the user whether or not the job has been considered by the negotiator.

Unfortunately, only the first job in the RRL gets the attribute update, meaning that all other jobs in the RRL get a user-unfriendly "this job has not been considered by the matchmaker" message - even though it's not true!
remarks:
2020-Mar-10 10:32:51 by pfc:
#usability

2020-May-12 10:56:16 by tlmiller:
Having the client figure out if we're in this case may be the least-awful way to do it. Another option is to just jettison this part of the diagnostic anyway -- it only helps if you're actually expecting your job to be scheduled during the first negotiator cycle anyway.

2020-Jun-02 09:41:55 by gthain:
After a long discussion, consensus was that users frequently don't care about condor_q -analyze <some random job in a big set>, they really want to easily analyze a set of jobs, and know how many are running, how many aren't, and why they aren't running. The UX today forces the person who runs condor_q to pick one job, but that's just our convenience speaking.

2020-Jul-21 10:19:04 by pfc:
Two action items:

1) Todd M. will implement the removal of the 1 line we all agree is unhelpful.

2) Christina will make a specific proposal for initial changes to the rest of the output based on her conversations with James et al, and LIGO will provide feedback. #7234

2020-Aug-18 11:46:47 by tim:
I think that we don't need a version history for this minor change.
derived_tickets: #7675   condor_q -analyze should summarize sets
check_ins: 2020-Jul-21 11:58   Check-in [60171]: (#5834, #7530) Remove 'Job has not yet been considered by the matchmaker.' as almost always wrong and almost never useful. (By Todd L Miller )
